boxed-text.title: Grants and Awards
boxed-text.p: The Captain Planet Foundation promotes and supports high-quality education programs that enable children and youth to understand and appreciate their world through learning experiences that engage them in active, hand-on projects to improve the environment in their schools and communities. The grants are intended to (a) serve as a catalyst to getting environment-based education in schools and (b) inspire youth and communities to participate in community service through environmental stewardship activities. Eligible applicants are U.S.-based schools. While the Foundation will on occasion consider grants up to US$2,500, preferential consideration is given to funding of US$500 or less and to applicants who have 50% matching or in-kind funding. Deadlines are May 31, September 30, and January 15. For more information, visit http://captainplanetfoundation.org/apply-for-grants/

The National Association of Independent Schools (NAIS) supports Challenge 20/20, an Internet-based program that pairs one school from the United States and one school from outside of the United States. Teacher–student teams from both schools work together throughout the fall 2012 school semester to find local solutions to one global problem. Challenge 20/20 is based on Jean Francois Rishcard’s book, High Noon: 20 Global Problems, 20 Years to Solve Them. Eligible applicants include all U.S. schools, elementary and secondary, and public or private. Schools need not be members of NAIS. At a school, the group of students participating may be part of a particular academic class or other group such as a club or afterschool activity. There is no cost to participate. The award is the international cooperation and collaboration between youth. The deadline is August 17, 2012. For more information, visit http://www.nais.org/resources/index.cfm?ItemNumber=147262/

The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA) Foundation advances the state of aerospace, engineering, and technical leadership. The Foundation funds classroom demonstration kits and science supplies, math and science software, supplies for making flying objects, supplies for robotic programs, and other materials that are related to a specific lesson plan. Each school is limited to up to two grants per calendar year. Eligible applicants are K-12 teachers who develop or apply science, mathematics, and technology in their curriculum. Awards are up to US$200 per individual request to supplement a learning program. Deadline is each April or June or until funding is exhausted. For more information, visit https://www.aiaa.org/Secondary.aspx?id=4184/

In2Books, a curriculum-based e-mentoring program from ePals, Inc., will be offered free to Title I schools. Students who participate in the program select and read age-appropriate, high-quality books from a list compiled by a team of children’s literature experts. The students are matched with carefully screened adult pen pals who read the same books as the students. After reading each book, students and their pen pals exchange thought about the important issues in the book via online letters. Teachers reinforce these activities in the classroom with related lessons and discussion. Eligible applicants are all third- to fifth-grade classrooms in Title I schools from any one district. Awards include the online program, books, and professional development (valued at more than US$500). For more information, visit http://in2books.epals.com/login.aspx?ReturnUrl=%2fdefault.aspx/

The InvenTeam Initiative, created by the Lemelson-MIT Program, provides an opportunity for high school students to cultivate their creativity and experience invention. InvenTeams are composed of high school students, teachers, and mentors who invent technological solutions to real-world problems. Each InvenTeam chooses its own problem to solve. InvenTeam projects span many fields from assistive devices to environmental technologies and consumer goods. Teams partner with professionals in their communities to enrich their experiences. A panel comprising inventors, educators, InvenTeam student alumni, and MIT faculty, staff, and alumni review the applications. Up to 35 finalists are selected from the initial applications to continue to the next step. Selected finalists receive Excite Awards and attend EurekaFest, a multi-day celebration at MIT in June. Excite Award winners must attend EurekaFest to submit a final InvenTeam grant application. Travel, food, and lodging are provided. Eligible applicants are science, math, and technology educators at high schools and nonprofit educational organizations that have not received an InvenTeam grant within the past 3 years. The optimal size of an InvenTeam is 5 to 15 high school youth. Grant size is US$10,000 with up to 15 awarded each year. Funds may be allocated for research, materials, and learning experiences related to the project but not to purchase capital equipment or professional services. Deadlines for the 2013-2014 have not yet been posted, but generally, the early feedback deadline is in March with the initial application due in April. For more information and invention ideas, visit http://web.mit.edu/inventeams/apply.html/.

The National Association for Biology Teachers (NABT) offers the following awards: The BioClub Student Award to an outstanding student member of a NABT BioClub, the Biology Educator Leadership Scholarship to encourage and support teachers who want to further their education in the life sciences or life science education, the Ecology/Environmental Science Teaching Award to a secondary school teacher who has successfully developed and demonstrated innovative approaches in the teaching of ecology/environmental science, the Evolution Education Award to educators involved in innovative classroom teaching and community education promoting the accurate understanding of biological evolution, and the Kim Foglia AP Biology Service Award to a teacher who displays a willingness to share materials and serves as a mentor. Each of these awards includes either financial or other forms of recognition. Deadline for submitting nominations is generally in March. For more information, visit http://www.nabt.org/websites/institution/index.php?p=132#award3/

The Harold W. McGraw, Jr. Prize in Education annually recognizes outstanding individuals who have dedicated themselves to improving education in this country and whose accomplishments are making a difference today. The Game Changer: Pioneer is awarded to an educational leader who has changed the way we think about a particular area of education and has developed a new concept or approach to teaching and learning. The Game Changer: Rising Star award is given to a relatively young researcher, practitioner, or policy maker who shows the promise of becoming a “game changer” in the future. The Game Changer: Luminary award is given to someone from outside the field of education who is passionate about education and has motivated others. During February, the McGraw-Hill Companies launch an outreach campaign to solicit nominations. By March, all nominations must be completed and received. A distinguished panel of judges then chooses the honorees by September of each year. Each winner receives a gift of US$50,000 and a bronze sculpture. For more information, visit http://www.mcgraw-hill.com/site/about-us/mcgraw-prize/

The Comcast Foundation awards grants for diversity-oriented programs that maximize the impact of community investments so they yield tangible, measurable benefits to the neighborhoods. Programs may address digital literacy, community service and volunteerism initiatives, and youth leadership development. Eligible applicants must be 501(c)(3) organizations operating within communities that Comcast serves. The maximum award is US$500,000. The deadline is rolling. For more information, visit http://www.comcast.com/corporate/about/inthecommunity/foundation/comcastfoundation.html?SCRedirect=true/

sec.title: Atlas Shrugged Essay Contest
sec.p: All high school seniors, college undergraduates, and graduate students are invited to submit an essay about Atlas Shrugged. These are the three topics that students can pick from: (a) What do you think Eddie Willers’ role is in the story? How does he help convey the novel’s theme? Why do you think his fate is left open in the last chapter? (b) Why does John Galt go on strike when the Starnes heirs take over the Twentieth Century Motor Company? Do you think he is right or wrong to start a strike? Explain. (c) Choose the scene in Atlas Shrugged that is most meaningful to you. Analyze that scene in terms of the wider themes in the book. Judges will look for clear, articulate writing and a demonstrated understanding of the philosophic meaning of the novel. There will be a blind judging process that will take place in four rounds. Essays will be checked for plagiarism. Applicants may only submit one essay. The first-prize winner will receive US$10,000, 3 second-prize winners will receive US$2,000, 5 third-prize winners will receive US$1,000, 25 finalists will receive US$100, and 50 semifinalists will receive US$50. Previous winners’ essays are available for viewing at the contest web site. Entries are due by September 17, 2012. For more information, please visit http://essaycontest.aynrandnovels.com/AtlasShrugged.aspx?theme=blue

sec.title: Discovering the Undiscovered Competition 2012
sec.p: The Grace Notes Foundation seeks to foster new writing talent and help writers accomplish their goals. Their hope is to reward excellent writers and bring their work into the public light. Writers founded the organization to meet the needs of aspiring writers and establish a social network for established writers. Any aspiring writer is welcome to submit a manuscript between 30,000 and 200,000 words. Manuscripts from the following categories are accepted: novels, novellas, memoirs, and works of creative nonfiction, collections of short fiction, creative essays, or a combination of two categories. Manuscripts should be uploaded through the electronic submission manager and include author contact information in the comments section of the submission form. The author’s name should not appear on the manuscript itself. At the time of submission, entrants can indicate if they would like feedback (for an additional fee). The winning author will receive a publication offer for their manuscript and the option of either a US$1,000 cash prize or an advance US$350 against royalties and a standard publishing contract of 15% of the cover price. Also, they will receive five contributor’s copies of their published book. All finalists may be considered for future publication. The final deadline for manuscript submissions is October 1, 2012. For more information, please visit http://gracenotesbooks.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=96&Itemid=103

sec.title: Bottle Tree One Act Play Competition Details
sec.p: The Bottle Tree One Act Play Competition is in its 4th year with a top prize of US$1,000. Scripts should be between 10 and 70 min long and in English. Previously produced and/or work-shopped scripts are acceptable as long as they were not produced or work-shopped by an equity company. Each entry should be accompanied with a US$25 entry free, and there is no limit to how many scripts can be entered. Judge feedback on the play can be requested for an additional US$50. Bottle Tree does not produce the winning entries but wants to help with promotion. The top 10 entries can submit a monologue from their play to be placed on the Bottle Tree monologues page. The contest ends on November 30, 2012. Scripts cannot be returned. For more information, please visit http://www.bottletreeinc.com/script_contest.html

sec.title: Look and Learn Art Competition
sec.p: Look and Learn is a picture library based in London specializing in educational images. They have held online children’s art competitions since 2006 with the goal of creating the best gallery of children’s art in the world. Each month, there is a new children’s art competition on a different theme. Every applicant receives a personalized participation certificate. Art entries are divided into three age groups: 0 to 7 years, 8 to 11 years, and 12 to 18 years of age. Only one entry per child can be accepted for each month. There are nine winners each month (three top winners from each age group). The first prize winner receives US$50, second prize receives US$35, third prize receives US$30, and highly commended prizes are US$20 (dollar amounts are approximate depending on the dollar and euro exchange rate). Closing dates for each competition are at the beginning of each month. Entries from past competitions are available for viewing on the contest web site. For more information, please visit http://art.lookandlearn.com/competition.php

sec.title: Education Matters US$5K Scholarship 2012
sec.p: ScholarshipExperts.com was founded in 2000 by a group of concerned education professionals, parents, and students trying to better serve the needs of college undergraduate and graduate students and college-bound high school seniors as they look for ways to pay for their education. Their mission is to provide a secure, time-saving and accurate scholarship search service. In 2012, ScholarshipExperts.com is offering the Education Matters US$5K Scholarship. Applicants must be 13 years old or older at the time of application and be currently enrolled (or enroll no later than the fall of 2018) in an accredited postsecondary institution of higher education. Applicants should complete an online scholarship search profile at ScholarshipExperts.com and submit an online 250-word (or less) response to the question: “What would you say to someone who thinks education doesn’t matter, or that college is a waste of time and money?” Students are limited to one entry per person. Judges will select one winner based on the following criteria: (a) writing ability (25%), (b) creativity (25%), (c) originality (25%), and (d) overall excellence (25%). The US$5,000 scholarship will be in the form of a check made payable to the accredited postsecondary institution of higher education attended by the winner. The scholarship recipient must submit proof of enrollment on or before December 31, 2018. The deadline for applications is October 31, 2012. The scholarship winner will be notified on or around December 15, 2012. For more information, please visit http://www.scholarshipexperts.com/rules.htx?selected=em
